text: Comparison of the transactivation domains of <extra_id_0> Stat5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Stat6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in lymphoid cells and mammary epithelial cells .
Stat ( signal transducers and activators of transcription ) and Jak ( Janus kinases ) proteins are central components in the signal transduction events in hematopoietic and epithelial cells .
They are rapidly activated by various cytokines , hormones , and growth factors .
Upon ligand binding and cytokine receptor dimerization , Stat proteins are phosphorylated on tyrosine residues by Jak kinases .
Activated Stat proteins form homo - or heterodimers , translocate to the nucleus , and induce transcription from responsive genes .
<extra_id_0> Stat5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Stat6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are transcription factors active in mammary epithelial cells and immune cells .

text: Both cytokines are able to stimulate cell proliferation , differentiation , and survival .
We investigated the transactivation potential of <extra_id_0> Stat6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and found that it is not restricted to lymphocytes .

text: In these cells , <extra_id_0> Stat6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation led to the induction of the beta-casein gene promoter .
The induction of this promoter was confirmed in COS7 cells .

The <extra_id_0> glucocorticoid receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was able to further enhance <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced gene transcription through the action of <extra_id_0> Stat6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: Deletion analysis of the carboxyl-terminal region of <extra_id_0> Stat6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and recombination of this region with a heterologous DNA binding domain allowed the delimitation and characterization of the transactivation domain of <extra_id_0> Stat6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

The potencies of the transactivation domains of <extra_id_0> Stat5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> Stat6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and viral protein <extra_id_0> VP16 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> were compared .
<extra_id_0> Stat6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> had a transactivation domain which was about 10-fold stronger than that of <extra_id_0> Stat5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

In pre-B cells ( Ba / F3 ) , the transactivation domain of <extra_id_0> Stat6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> regulated , independently from its DNA binding function .
